block.p: A NEW SIDE TO VERMONT -- Vermont, which offers American companies lucrative tax breaks through unusual insurance arrangements, now rivals the Cayman Islands and Bermuda as the insurance destination of choice for many companies. [Page C1.]

GETTING IN ON GLOBAL POSITIONING -- The United States monopoly on satellite navigation is about to be challenged. Russia plans to launch eight navigation satellites by the end of the year, seeking to take on a role as navigation technology becomes ubiquitous in the economy. [C1.]

A BROADER SENSE OF OUTSOURCING -- The outsourcing of jobs to countries like India has increasingly included the jobs of Western white-collar elites, in fields as diverse as investment banking, aircraft engineering and pharmaceutical research. [C1.]

ANOTHER TRY FOR TRIBUNE? -- Eli Broad and Ronald W. Burkle, the two Los Angeles billionaires who lost the auction for the Tribune Company to Samuel Zell, reconvened with advisers to consider making a new bid for the company, according to a person close to them. [C1.]

TAX PREPARER FRAUD -- The Justice Department took steps to shut down franchises of the Jackson Hewitt tax preparation chain, charging that more than 165 stores had enabled thousands of customers to fraudulently obtain $70 million by falsifying tax returns. The I.R.S. commissioner, Mark Everson, above, said that the government's action was limited to certain franchises, not the Jackson Hewitt headquarters. [C3.]

U.S. SUES ANTITAX ADVOCATE -- The leader of a nationwide movement that contends most Americans are not required to pay income tax was sued by the Justice Department, which said that his followers had used his scheme to avoid paying $21 million in income taxes. [C3.]

AUTO SALES IN MARCH -- General Motors, Ford Motor and the Chrysler division of DaimlerChrysler all reported declines in dealership sales in March. Toyota, meanwhile, reported an increase of 7.7 percent, and sales of its Prius doubled. [C3.]
RECORD SPEED ON RAILS -- A French high-speed train broke the world speed record on rail, reaching 357 miles an hour in a test. [C4.]

BUYOUT FOR AUSTRALIAN RETAILER -- A consortium has offered to buy the troubled retailer Coles, the second-largest retailer in Australia, on terms that would make it the largest takeover attempt in Australia. [C3.]

STATES EMBOLDENED ON CLIMATE -- President Bush said that he did not intend to use his authority to regulate the gases that cause climate change. But the Supreme Court's Monday decision is creating political momentum in a growing number of states to bypass the Bush administration and make their own rules. [A1.]

NEWS CORP. ASSET SWAP APPROVED -- Shareholders of the News Corporation have approved an $11 billion asset swap that increases Rupert Murdoch's control over the company and transfers the DirecTV Group to Liberty Media, controlled by John C. Malone. Under the agreement, signed in December, the News Corporation will buy back Liberty's 16.3 percent stake in the company, raising the Murdoch family's stake in the News Corporation to 38 percent, from 31 percent. [C6.]

DOUBLECLICK'S NEW VENTURE -- DoubleClick, which delivers marketing messages to Web sites and monitors how many clicks they get, plans to announce that it is setting up a Nasdaq-like exchange for the buying and selling of digital advertisements. Advertising. [C6.]

HOUSING DATA HELP STOCKS SOAR -- Shares surged, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average to a five-week high, as the housing market and consumers showed signs of resilience and falling oil prices gave investors an extra reason to rally. [C11.]
OFFICES RESURGENT IN MANHATTAN -- The strength of Manhattan's commercial property market is causing developers to rethink plans to convert aging office buildings into residential condominiums. [C8.]

JPMORGAN MAY BUILD SKYSCRAPER -- JPMorgan Chase is in negotiations to build a 1.3-million-square-foot skyscraper in Manhattan near ground zero and bring thousands of employees downtown from Midtown, according to government officials involved in the negotiations. [B1.]

JAILED VIDEOGRAPHER IS RELEASED -- A freelance videographer and blogger was released from jail, eight months after he was incarcerated for refusing to turn over a tape of a violent protest, ending what has been called the longest incarceration ever of an American journalist. [A9.]

THE EXECUTIVE PAY PACKAGE -- The latest on the compensation packages of corporate executives, gleaned from proxy statements and other documents, and interactive features on executive pay are at nytimes.com/business.

TIGHTENING MORTGAGE REINS -- A growing number of New Yorkers, often with six-figure salaries and reasonably good credit, have begun to find that mortgages are harder to get as lenders try to stem losses from loans to the weakest, or subprime, borrowers. A report and slide show are at nytimes.com/realestate.

MANHATTAN MULTITASKERS -- On bicycle, on foot and often behind the wheel, users of digital devices present potentially dangerous situations every day. A report and slide show are at nytimes.com/multimedia.
